{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3752446,"name":"","username":"TomT","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tomt/{size}/263451_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-30T17:41:27.827Z","cooked":"

I’m working on testing using a primary sketch in Fusion, similar to what is outlined at FRCDesign.

I can make a primary sketch and use derive to bring it into a fusion design. Using project, you can use that to create things like square tubing that is driven from the sketch with minimal dimensioning. Using “FRCTools for Fusion”, I can tubify those, but it’s a one-time operation which is not ideal. i can also joint a component to a sketch line, which I think will be much more reliable than students creating a joint to whatever they feel.

Fusion can’t change the colors of sketch lines, but you can cheat a little on visualizations and use the surface patch tool to give them a 2D surface that allows you to assign an appearance.

I have not found a good option for creating multiple pose configurations in the primary sketch (ex robot in start form, robot in full extent mode) aside from driving parameters from configurations and using them to drive the different poses. I have not fully tested that yet.

I don’t fully understand the concept of the Onshape view cube featurescript, so I’m not sure how to translate that into something useful in Fusion.

Is anyone else trying to adopt some of the FRCDesign best practices in Fusion?

(I’ll be at the Firebears MRI this weekend if anyone wants to talk shop)

Going to be completely honest - FRCdesign is completely designed around Onshape, it’ll be very difficult to properly mimic what it does. Maybe for viewing different poses - try out Onshape! Lots of teams use it to view robots in easily changeable positions via the configuration tool.

While I can personally tinker with Onshape to learn more, Onshape is off the table for the current season, primarily at the school’s direction. It’s something we are working on, but it’s Fusion for the foreseeable future - so we’re making the best of the tools at our disposal.

ah - fair enough, our team was also in the same situation. the school we’re hosted at primarily teaches Fusion 360 but I transitioned us a team over to Onshape and we’ll be teaching kids the program in a few days.

Curious. What can the school do to stop you from getting a mentor’s acct ( 0 cost education/competition acct and you can create a team folder as well as doing classes using FRCDesign.org) and then having all your students to signup for a free student account? It runs 100% on the browser. So unless they are actively blocking OnShape, there’s not much that they can do to prevent you from using both.

I’m in the process of migrating us to OnShape now and getting the students into a class and I can finally get to ‘track’ whether they have actually done the exercises or not. CAM was holding us back but CAM is going to be available to FRC teams (see Drew’s posting in another thread).

tkchan:

So unless they are actively blocking OnShape, there’s not much that they can do to prevent you from using both.

We utilize the school’s computers and network, so yes, they can block it if it’s not approved.
